Apply Your Knowledge

These scenarios simulate real customer conversations youâ€™ll encounter as a CSM or CSA. Practice how youâ€™d respond using SDLC concepts.

Scenario 1: The â€œWeâ€™re Fineâ€ Customer

Situation

Customer: FinServe Bank (500 developers)

Context: Quarterly business review (QBR). Theyâ€™ve used GitHub for 2 years but havenâ€™t adopted new features.

The VP of Engineering says:

â€œWeâ€™re happy with GitHub. We use it for source control and thatâ€™s really all we need. Our current process works fine â€” developers commit code, it goes through a manual review process, QA tests for two weeks, and we release quarterly.â€

Your Task

How do you identify opportunities and start a conversation about expanding their GitHub usage?

Show Suggested Approach

What you heard: - Only using for source control (underutilization) - Manual review process (no automation) - 2-week QA cycle (long testing phase) - Quarterly releases (slow delivery)

Questions to ask: 1. â€œHow long does it typically take from when a developer finishes a feature to when customers see it?â€ 2. â€œWhat does your manual review process look like? How many people are involved?â€ 3. â€œWhat happens when you need to deploy an urgent security fix?â€

Bridge to value: - Lead time sounds long â€” â€œMany of our customers have reduced this from months to daysâ€ - Manual testing is expensive â€” â€œWhat if you could automate 80% of that?â€ - Quarterly releases = higher risk â€” â€œSmaller, more frequent releases often reduce deployment failuresâ€

Features to introduce: 1. GitHub Actions for automated testing 2. Branch protection for streamlined reviews 3. GitHub Advanced Security for continuous security

Conversation tip: Donâ€™t tell them theyâ€™re doing it wrong. Ask questions that help them see the cost of their current process.

Scenario 2: The Migration Customer

Situation

Customer: TechStart (startup, 30 developers)

Context: Theyâ€™re migrating from GitLab to GitHub Enterprise Cloud.

The CTO says:

â€œWe moved to GitHub because our investors use it and we needed better security features. But honestly, Iâ€™m not sure weâ€™re getting value yet. Our team keeps complaining about the transition and weâ€™re not seeing the productivity gains we expected.â€

Your Task

How do you help them realize value during this critical adoption phase?

Show Suggested Approach

Red flags: - Team complaints = adoption friction - No perceived value = churn risk - Investor-driven decision = not bottom-up buy-in

Discovery questions: 1. â€œWhat specific complaints are you hearing from the team?â€ 2. â€œWhat were they doing in GitLab that they canâ€™t do in GitHub?â€ 3. â€œWhat does â€˜productivity gainsâ€™ look like to you â€” how would you measure it?â€

Common migration pain points: - CI/CD pipeline translation (GitLab CI â†’ GitHub Actions) - Different workflow (GitLab MRs vs GitHub PRs) - Feature parity gaps (perceived or real) - Learning curve on new UI

Your action plan: 1. Office hours session â€” Walk through GitHub Actions vs GitLab CI 2. Quick wins â€” Show something they couldnâ€™t do before: - GitHub Copilot demos - Security alerts catching real vulnerabilities - Codespaces for instant dev environments 3. Success metrics â€” Help them define what success looks like: - PR cycle time - Build success rate - Time to onboard new developer

Key message: â€œLetâ€™s identify 2-3 quick wins that show immediate value while we work on the longer-term improvements.â€

Scenario 3: The Security-Focused Customer

Situation

Customer: HealthTech Inc. (200 developers, HIPAA-regulated)

Context: New customer, post-sales handoff meeting.

The CISO says:

â€œWe bought GitHub because of GHAS (GitHub Advanced Security), but I need to show my board that weâ€™re actually more secure now. Theyâ€™re going to ask about our vulnerability count in 90 days. How do I prove ROI?â€

Your Task

How do you help them demonstrate security value?

Show Suggested Approach

Their need: Quantifiable security metrics for board reporting

Phase 1: Enable visibility (Week 1-2) 1. Enable secret scanning on all repos 2. Enable Dependabot security updates 3. Enable code scanning on top 10 critical repos

Phase 2: Measure baseline (Week 2-4) - Document current vulnerability count - Categorize by severity (Critical, High, Medium, Low) - Note mean time to remediation for any existing issues

Phase 3: Show progress (Week 4-12) Track and report: - Vulnerabilities prevented â€” Secrets blocked before commit - Vulnerabilities found â€” Code scanning alerts - Vulnerabilities fixed â€” Dependabot auto-PRs merged - MTTR â€” Time from alert to fix

Board-ready metrics:

Before GHAS: Unknown vulnerability count
After 90 days:
- 47 critical secrets blocked
- 156 vulnerabilities identified
- 89% auto-fixed by Dependabot
- MTTR reduced from unknown to 3 days

Your deliverable: Help them create a simple dashboard or report template they can use for board meetings.

Scenario 4: The DevOps Transformation

Situation

Customer: RetailCorp (2,000 developers)

Context: Executive sponsor call. Theyâ€™re 18 months into a â€œDevOps transformationâ€ initiative.

The VP of Platform Engineering says:

â€œOur DevOps transformation is stalling. Weâ€™ve been preaching CI/CD for over a year but only 20% of teams have adopted it. Leadership is questioning whether GitHub is the right platform. How do we accelerate adoption?â€

Your Task

How do you help them drive organization-wide adoption?

Show Suggested Approach

Diagnose the problem: 1. â€œWhat do the 20% who adopted have in common?â€ 2. â€œWhat are the other 80% citing as barriers?â€ 3. â€œIs there executive sponsorship and are there consequences for not adopting?â€

Common adoption barriers: - Skills gap â€” Teams donâ€™t know how to write CI/CD - Time â€” â€œWe donâ€™t have time to learn new toolsâ€ - Fear â€” Automation means less control - No mandate â€” Optional â†’ not prioritized

Acceleration strategies:

1. Make it easy (reduce friction) - Create reusable workflow templates - Build a â€œstarter kitâ€ repo teams can fork - Offer Codespaces for zero-setup onboarding

2. Make it visible (social proof) - Publicize early adopter success stories - Create internal leaderboard/gamification - Executive shoutouts for teams that adopt

3. Make it required (guardrails) - Branch protection requiring CI checks - No deployments without Actions pipeline - Compliance requirements for security scans

4. Make it supported (enablement) - Champions program in each business unit - Regular office hours - Internal documentation and FAQs

Your offer: â€œLetâ€™s do a pilot with 5 teams who want to adopt but havenâ€™t yet. Weâ€™ll create templates and document the process, then scale what works.â€

Scenario 5: The â€œWe Need Trainingâ€ Request

Situation

Customer: ManuTech (300 developers)

Context: Inbound request from your customer.

The Engineering Manager emails:

â€œHi, our team needs GitHub training. We just hired 50 new developers and theyâ€™re struggling with our workflow. Can you provide training?â€

Your Task

How do you respond effectively to this request?

Show Suggested Approach

Donâ€™t just say â€œyes, hereâ€™s training.â€ Dig deeper first.

Discovery email response: > â€œHappy to help with training! To make sure we address the right topics, could you share: > 1. What aspects are they struggling with most? > 2. What does your current workflow look like? > 3. Have they used Git/GitHub before, or is this brand new? > 4. What does success look like after training?â€

Common underlying issues: - No documentation â€” They need internal onboarding docs, not generic training - Complex workflow â€” The process is hard, not GitHub - Tool overload â€” They use 10 tools and GitHub is just one more - Manager expectations â€” Managers expect immediate productivity

Your options: 1. GitHub Skills â€” Self-paced, free, covers basics 2. GitHub Professional Services â€” Custom training for specific workflows 3. Partner training â€” Certified partners offer training programs 4. Internal champions â€” Train the trainers approach 5. Documentation help â€” Help them create internal guides

Value-add opportunity: â€œBeyond training, letâ€™s look at whether there are workflow improvements that would make onboarding easier for everyone â€” not just new hires.â€
